extendedIngredients.name: curry powder
extendedIngredients.originalString: 4 to 5 tablespoons Jamaican curry powder (spicy or non spicy)

extendedIngredients.name: ginger
extendedIngredients.originalString: A 2-inch piece of ginger, peeled and minced (about 2 tablespoons minced)

extendedIngredients.name: low sodium chicken broth
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 quart cups water or low-sodium chicken broth

extendedIngredients.name: meat
extendedIngredients.originalString: 3 pounds bone-in goat meat for stew (about 2-inch chunks)

extendedIngredients.name: russet potatoes
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 medium russet potatoes, peeled and cut into 1-inch cubes (about 2 cups)

extendedIngredients.name: scotch bonnet chili peppers
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 to 3 haba√±ero or Scotch bonnet peppers, seeded and chopped

recipes.title: Jamaican Goat Curry

winePairing.pairingText: Asian can be paired with Riesling, Gewurztraminer, and Chenin Blanc. The best wine for Asian food depends on the cuisine and dish - of course - but these acidic whites pair with a number of traditional meals, spicy or not. One wine you could try is Pacific Rim Riesling. It has 4.2 out of 5 stars and a bottle costs about 12 dollars.

productMatches.title: Pacific Rim Riesling
productMatches.description: Portraying bright crispness, subtle sweetness and aromas of jasmine, pear and apple, Pacific Rim Riesling exemplifies the harmony of Riesling. The sweetness plays wonderfully with fiery fare (from Thai to Mexican), while the natural acidity stands up to richer foods (from French to German).

recipes.instructions: Procedures                                                                              1                                                                            Heat 2 tablespoons oil in a 3 quart saucepan or dutch oven over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add 1/3 of goat to pan and brown on all sides, about 6 minutes. Transfer to a plate. Repeat with remaining goat in two more batches, adding additional oil as necessary and controlling heat to prevent burning.                                                                                                                            2                                                                            Return pan to heat and add onions and garlic. Cook, stirring frequently, until onions are softened, about 4 minutes. Add curry powder and cook, stirring constantly until fragrant, about 30 seconds.                                                                                                                            3                                                                            Add ginger and pepper and cook, stirring frequently, until fragrant, about 1 minute. Add the water or chicken broth to the pot, along with the browned meat. Add 2 teaspoons kosher salt. Scrape up any browned bits from bottom of pot. Bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer, cover the pot, and cook for 1 1/2 hours. Add potatoes and continue cooking until goat is completely tender, 30 minutes to 1 hour longer.                                                                                                                            4                                                                            Skim the fat off the broth.  Or, let the curry cool and place it into the refrigerator.  Skim off the solidified fat on top.  Warm the curry again. Season to taste with more salt, and serve.

steps.step: Heat 2 tablespoons oil in a 3 quart saucepan or dutch oven over medium-high heat until shimmering.
Add 1/3 of goat to pan and brown on all sides, about 6 minutes.
Transfer to a plate. Repeat with remaining goat in two more batches, adding additional oil as necessary and controlling heat to prevent burning.
Return pan to heat and add onions and garlic. Cook, stirring frequently, until onions are softened, about 4 minutes.
Add curry powder and cook, stirring constantly until fragrant, about 30 seconds.
Add ginger and pepper and cook, stirring frequently, until fragrant, about 1 minute.
Add the water or chicken broth to the pot, along with the browned meat.
Add 2 teaspoons kosher salt. Scrape up any browned bits from bottom of pot. Bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer, cover the pot, and cook for 1 1/2 hours.
Add potatoes and continue cooking until goat is completely tender, 30 minutes to 1 hour longer.
Skim the fat off the broth.  Or, let the curry cool and place it into the refrigerator.  Skim off the solidified fat on top.  Warm the curry again. Season to taste with more salt, and serve.
